learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate a knowledge and an understanding of the fundamental principles and rules of law and the general practice of dealings with property rights in Queensland.
A knowledge and understanding of legal principles by analysing and critically examining fundamental aspects of property law in a logical and organised fashion.
Analyse and interpret relevant case law and statutes in the context of property law.
Demonstrate skills in legal research and written communication.
Critically evaluate the implications of the rules of property law and explore the possibilities for reform within the context of society as a whole.

assessments.task_description:
Students must submit one-to-two A4 pages of handwritten answers to the week's tutorial question/s. Students will be awarded 1.5 marks for the identification and treatment of the issues relevant to solving that week's tutorial question. Over the course of the semester, students can attain a maximum of 10 marks for this assessment item. In other words, students need only submit seven out of 11 answers to receive the full 10 marks.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: To be eligible for the 1.5 marks, you must submit your handwritten tutorial answers to your tutor at the beginning of the tutorial and attend the entire tutorial.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The In-Semester Examination will be held in the Advanced Engineering Building, Room 49-200 between 4.00 – 6.00 p.m. on 27 August 2025. Further information about the content, format and marking criteria of the In-Semester Examination will be provided on Learn.UQ once the Chief Examiner has approved the examination paper.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Any written or printed material is permitted in the exam. Material may also be annotated. The exam will comprise up to four questions, which may be compulsory. One or more of the questions may be broken down into individual parts. The examination paper will indicate the proportion of the marks given to each question (and to individual parts within a question where applicable). The examination paper may consist of problem-style and/or essay-style questions, or mixed problem- / essay-style questions, of varying weightings and length. Any of the questions may combine material from different aspects of the examinable topics in the course. Further information about the content, format and marking criteria of the final examination will be provided on Learn.UQ once the Chief Examiner has approved the examination paper.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Co-ownership

Lecture on the basic concepts of co-ownership; joint tenancies versus tenancies in common; determination of co-ownership.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Co-ownership Lecture on the basic concepts of co-ownership; joint tenancies versus tenancies in common; determination of co-ownership.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Easements

Lecture on essential characteristics of easements, creation and enforcement of easements, extinguishment of easements, profits à prendre, statutory covenants.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Easements Lecture on essential characteristics of easements, creation and enforcement of easements, extinguishment of easements, profits à prendre, statutory covenants.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Co-ownership

Tutorial exercise based on material from Week 1.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Co-ownership Tutorial exercise based on material from Week 1.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Community Title Schemes and Body Corporates I

Lecture on the history of strata title schemes, key concepts of BCCMA, establishing a community titles scheme, types of community titles scheme, Community Management Statements. Since Wednesday 16 August 2025 is a public holiday, this week's lecture will be uploaded directly to Learn.UQ.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 3: Community Title Schemes and Body Corporates I
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Community Title Schemes and Body Corporates I Lecture on the history of strata title schemes, key concepts of BCCMA, establishing a community titles scheme, types of community titles scheme, Community Management Statements. Since Wednesday 16 August 2025 is a public holiday, this week's lecture will be uploaded directly to Learn.UQ.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Easements

Tutorial exercise based on material from Week 2.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Easements Tutorial exercise based on material from Week 2.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Community Title Schemes and Body Corporates II / Leasehold Interests in Land I

Lecture on lots and lot owners, the Body Corporate governance of community titles schemes, dispute resolution, termination of a community titles scheme. The lecture will also introduce students to the course and the "lease" versus "licence" distinction, the elements and types of leases, as well as the creation of leasehold interests in land (including formalities).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 4: Community Title Schemes and Body Corporates II / Leasehold Interests in Land I
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Community Title Schemes and Body Corporates II / Leasehold Interests in Land I Lecture on lots and lot owners, the Body Corporate governance of community titles schemes, dispute resolution, termination of a community titles scheme. The lecture will also introduce students to the course and the "lease" versus "licence" distinction, the elements and types of leases, as well as the creation of leasehold interests in land (including formalities).

Lecture on Native Title Act 1993 (Cth) (including proof and claim procedures, extinguishment, validation and confirmation of extinguishment, the "future acts" regime, and Indigenous Land Use Agreements).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
